abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional Trade
            Facilitation Project for Africa were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: African trade
            insurance (ATI) agency plays a public sector role as a
            multilateral agency owned by multiple states, which provides
            legitimacy, allows preferred creditor status, and
            facilitates healthy peer pressure among member states to
            honor financial commitments. Imbedding self-correction and
            self-supervision mechanisms in client agencies minimizes the
            need for the Bank to play the role of a de facto regulator,
            for which it does not necessarily have sufficient resources,
            expertise, or enforcement mandate. The presence of a
            significant number of independent directors competitively
            selected for their specialized expertise in accordance with
            an agreed competence matrix may also play a critical role as
            ATI progresses towards self-supervision. More attention
            should have been given by the Bank to understanding the
            specific demand in Africa in terms of market needs, product
            mix, targeted clients, and transaction origination channels.
            Operational manuals, technical assistance, and training,
            while all necessary, are not sufficient mechanisms to ensure
            that a public sector entity like ATI will be able to keep
            pace with its internationally competitive peers and without
            taking excessive risks. Political and commercial risk
            insurance continues to be a key instrument needed to support
            private trade and investment flows in Africa.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Regional Trade Facilitation
            Project : restructuring of development credits for Uganda,
            Tanzania, Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Burundi, Rwanda, Congo and Madagascar

abstracts.cdata!:
While performance of the regional trade
            facilitation project for Africa is satisfactory, the project
            has fallen short of its potential due to the restrictive
            capital structure of the Africa Trade Insurance Agency (ATI)
            and a misalignment of products offered by ATI with market
            requirements. Three changes are proposed: (i) capital
            restructuring of ATI; (ii) expansion of product lines
            offered; and (iii) consolidation of the existing individual
            IDA projects under a single project number. These
            modifications (i and ii) will help solidify ATI's
            capacity to deliver on its mandate to facilitate productive
            trade and investment for member states while the third
            proposed change (iii) will realign World Bank processes to
            ensure a regional approach to development.

12495960.trustfund:

            OPERATIONS MANUAL,TF093331-REGIONAL TRADE FACILITATION PROJECT,TF040119-KENYA: DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL

repnme.cdata!: Africa Region - Regional Trade Facilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Regional Trade Facilitation Project
            will contribute to poverty alleviation, through private
            sector led growth in the participating countries, by
            improving access to financing for productive transactions,
            and cross-border trade. The two components will: 1) Support
            the establishment of a regional political insurance
            facility, to be implemented, and managed by a multilateral
            agency, i.e., the African Trade Insurance Agency (ATI). The
            facility will cover productive activity involving
            cross-border trade, and, political/non-commercial risks,
            which include inter alia, inability to convert, or transfer
            currency; imposition of exchange controls; cancellation of
            licenses/restrictions on import/export; and, seizure of
            goods, prevention of sale, or of export. 2) ATI's
            operating, and capital costs will be shared by the
            participating countries, and a credit from the International
            Development Association (IDA) will cover the start-up period
            of ATI's operation. Each country's share will be
            proportional to the level of ATI's activity, related to
            transaction, covering imports into, and exports out of each
            country. A fund will be created for capital expenses to be
            incurred during the life of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Guarantee Facility Project
            : environment operations manual

abstracts.cdata!:
The Guarantee Facility Project in the
            Africa Region will help the Common Market for Eastern and
            Southern Africa (COMESA), fulfill its vision of an
            integrated, internationally competitive, regional economic
            community, by increasing development cooperation, trade, and
            investment promotion. The project will provide development
            assistance, by setting up credible insurance mechanisms,
            against losses caused by political risks, through the
            provision of technical support, which requires the
            pre-requisite of sound environmental, and sustainable
            practices. This environmental operations manual (EOM)
            outlines environmental assessment guidelines for each
            project transaction, to be categorized by the African Trade
            Insurance Agency (ATI), based on the applicants'
            Environmental Information Note. The EOM identifies
            environmental standards within: environmental quality
            standards (air, water, or soil pollution); emission
            standards; product standards (use/disposal of products);
            process, and production standards; and, performance
            standards. Environmental principles, and methods of
            screening are outlined, where each category is defined,
            highlighting the environmental scope per
            category-transaction activity, to then provide guidance on
            the implementation of environmental assessments, its
            processes, monitoring by the national environmental
            assessment authorities, to finally review country specific
            environmental regulations.

display_title.display_title:
Africa Region - Guarantee
            Facility Project : environment operations manual :
            Environmental operations manual
